docs.lead_paragraph: I was delighted to see a column on ethics in the magazine, but dismayed by the answer given by Randy Cohen to L.C., who asked when she should tell prospective employers about her pregnancy (The Ethicist, Aug. 15). I see the need for extended leave as the issue, not the pregnancy itself.
docs.abstract: Anne Barton letter lauds presence of ethics column but expreses dismay at Randy Cohen's August 15 answer to L C on question of whether she should tell prospective employers about her pregnancy (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: As he wanders the nation prophesying a political apocalypse, Alan L. Keyes, the staunchly conservative radio talk show host, is the invisible man in the race for the Republican Presidential nomination. He gets few cameras at his events. Political analysts tend to forget him in their prognostications. Polls show him receiving 1 percent of the vote or less. And when the Log Cabin Republicans, a homosexual group, issued a news release recently criticizing culturally conservative candidates for intolerance, Mr. Keyes did not even merit a mention.

headline.main: Keyes Draws the Few, but Devoted

docs.abstract: Article in series The Contenders, on Presidential aspirants, focuses on black conservative Republican Alan L Keyes, who is largely ignored by press and political prognosticators; Keyes, radio talk show host, has attracted small, devoted cadre of followers with his oratorical skills and messianic vision; says goal is to address moral issues, not win, interview; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Abortion opponents marshaled their forces today to try to find a 14-year-old Arizona girl who was believed to be in Kansas for a late-term abortion, and to stop her from having the procedure. On Sunday, the Arizona Supreme Court ruled that the girl, a ward of the Maricopa County Superior Court who said she became pregnant after being raped, could be taken to Kansas for the procedure. The girl, who had been a ward of the state since she was 5, is at least 24 weeks pregnant, and although Arizona law allows late-term abortions, doctors in the state generally do not perform them after 20 weeks of pregnancy. The girl had requested an abortion 14 weeks into the pregnancy but then ran away, returning only recently.

headline.main: National News Briefs; Kansas Abortion Foes Seek 14-Year-Old Girl

docs.abstract: Abortion opponents seek to find and prevent 14-year-old Arizona girl from having late-term abortion in Kansas; Arizona court ruled girl could be taken to Kansas for procedure, which is legal but rarely performed in Arizona (M)
